author: ralexstokes
content: aiui the findings w/ trinity have essentially been that "`asyncio` doesn't scale" as your use case gets more complex

author: ralexstokes
content: if you notice having issues w/ getting `pyrum` to do what you want then i'd consider looking at `trio`

author: ralexstokes
content: it is basically the Go concurrency model written in python

author: protolambda
content: So far it has been very elegant to work with asyncio, since we move all true concurrency to Rumor anyway.

author: ralexstokes
content: and when i say "doesn't scale" what i mean in particular is issues w/ cancellations actually doing the cancelling

author: ralexstokes
content: great -- but `trio` is at least worth being aware of

author: protolambda
content: You mean, futures not completing? Or not being able to stop a future?

author: protolambda
content: At this point Pyrum is small enough to rewrite it in an hour or two if you've the right idea (knowing what it does now, why it works), I'm not too worried, but will keep an eye out for trio if we have tests with flaky async behavior

author: ralexstokes
content: i think a little of both but other trinity team members have more direct experience w/ it

author: ralexstokes
content: the other thing to be aware of is that you can't mix usage of `asyncio` and `trio` in the same process
